PREVENTION PROGRAM FOR THE CHLORINE PROCESS

Chlorine is the most common oxidant used in water treatment.  NIWC uses chlorine from pressurized metal cylinders.  Chlorine is added to water by evaporating chlorine liquid to gas, metering the gas into water through an injector and then diffusing the solution into the flow stream at the point of application.

NIWC's prevention program for this process consists of a Management System, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Contractor Safety, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Safe Work Practices, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning, Compliance Audits and Training.  An explanation follows:

Management System- The purpose of the management system is to ensure that employees are involved in the development, implementation, and maintenance of the RMP/PSM Program and understand their roles and responsibilities and that responsibility is assigned for all elements of the program.

Process Safety Information- Process safety information is developed and maintained in a format that provides easy access by employees and auditors.  Information on the hazards of chlorine, feed process technology and process equipment is kept up to date.

Process hazard Analysis- A "What-if" process hazard analysis is performed to evaluate and control the risks associated with chlorine feed process hazards.  The overall purpose of the PHA is to prevent or minimize the effects of a chemical release.  

Operating Procedures-  Operating procedures are required for all stages of system operation.  Northern Illinois Water Corporation maintains up-to-date, accurate written procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in the chlorine feed process.

Contractor Safety-  Only contractors with safe work histories and safety and health programs are selected to perform work on or around chlorine system.

Management of Change/Pre-Startup Reviews-  This portion of the prevention program ensures that process changes and new systems are ready to operate safely in accordance with the original or new system design.

Mechanical Integrity-  This portion of the program addresses the following:
* Critical equipment
* Inspection schedules
* Maintenance training
* Maintenance documentation

Equipment involved in the process is listed below:
* Piping/Valves
* Evaporators
* Expansion chamber
* Pressure relief devices
* Vacuum regulators
* Injectors
* Chlorine detectors




Safe Work Practices-  Company employees, contractor employees and visitors must adhere to all safety rules and procedures.  Some of the safe work practices utilized in the maintenance/operation of the chlorine feed process are as follows:

* Hot Work Permit
* Lockout/Tagout
* Line opening Procedures
* Plant Security- Sign In/ Sign Out
* Confined Space

14. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY/RMP SUBMIT

14.1 CORPORATE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE APPROACHES

At this facility, IAWC handle chlorine for the purpose of disinfecting and treating drinking water.  OSHA and EPA consider chlorine a hazardous chemical.  The hazards of chlorine make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in the use and handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is IAWC policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends on the manner chlorine is handled and used, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design along with operating procedures and the training of our personnel.

The emergency action plan is based upon OSHA 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans) 1910.120 (Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response) and experience obtained from community drills.

14.2 THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

? The maximum amount of chlorine stored at this location is 20,000 pounds.
? The chlorine is delivered by truck in one-ton cylinders.  Liquid chlorine is added to water by evaporating chlorine liquid to gas, metering the gas through an injector, and then diffusing the gas into the flow stream of water at the point of application.

14.3 THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE INCLUDING ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCES FOR EACH REPORTED SCENARIO

A.    Worst -Case Scenario:
? Failure of the largest vessel when full would allow a release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine for a 10 minute duration.
? Distance to the end point at 770 F would travel 2.6 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.

B. Alternative-Case Scenario:
? A tubing failure due to a bad connection or valve failure resulting in the release through a 5/16 inch diameter opening allowing a rele

ase rate of 10.5 pounds per minute for a 60 minute duration for a total release of 317 pounds of chlorine.
? Distance to the endpoint at 770 F would travel 0.48 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.
14.4 THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

? This facility and process uses design codes and standards from the Chlorine Institute, Wallace and Tierman Manuals, American National Standards Institute, American Society for Testing and Materials, and applicable state codes and regulations.

14.5 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

?  We have had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.

14.6 THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

? The written emergency response program as mentioned in the opening paragraph is located at the facility with an ongoing training program.

14.7 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

? Although there is no immediate plans for changes to improve safety at this facility, we constantly review advancement in safety and process technology for the continuing pursuit to provide a safer workplace and community.
